item.title: Save Your Research
item.description:
My 2 Cents on Sharing Your Research (Or How Not to Get Lost in the Data Jungle)

Sharing research data is like hosting a party. You want everything to be in the right place, accessible to everyone, but not too chaotic. Let’s navigate the data jungle together, shall we?

Possible Data Repositories

  • Harvard Dataverse: Great if you’re a minimalist, with a cap of 1TB per researcher. Supports only JSON and XML, so it’s like a party with a strict dress code.

  • Zenodo: The friendly neighbor who never says no. Unlimited space, supports everything, and even merged with Dryad.

  • Dryad: Must involve your institution. It’s like needing a chaperone for a night out.

  • Figshare: Got categories? Figshare is the librarian of data sharing.

  • Mendeley Data: Like a sophisticated social club for data enthusiasts.

  • OSF: If data repositories had a welcoming committee, OSF would be it.

  • VIVLI: The specialized clinic for clinical research data. Not for the faint of heart!

  • F1000Research: It’s there if you need it. Kind of like your in-laws.

If you’re the indecisive type and need a full-on spreadsheet to make your life choices, here’s a comparison chart.

Sharing Tips (or How to be the Life of the Data Party)

  • For Datasets: Zenodo is your buffet table of unlimited choices. More on Zenodo & Dryad’s merger.

  • For Presentations: f1000research, where slide decks go to party. No limit means the dance floor is always open.

    • If you want to share everything (e.g., data, slides, posters, etc.) in one place (i.e., project), Figshare is your best bet (but it’s just not my personal favorite).

  • For Code or Procedures: Zenodo again! They’re like that friend who’s good at everything. Even better, publish your documentation as an article on the Journal of Open Source Software (my personal favorite) or the Journal of Open Research Software

The Last Crumb

Remember, these repositories are like different rooms at a party. They all come with a DOI and support an embargo period (that’s the bouncer keeping things under control). Choose wisely, or you might end up in the metaphorical coatroom of the data-sharing party.

Happy sharing and don’t get lost in the data jungle!

item.title: Patent Databases
item.description:
Comprehensive patent data can be found here

United States

  • NBER patent data or link
    • Search link for individual patent: link
    • Patent API
  • USPTO - United States patent and Trademark Office
    • Patent ranking by orgs
    • Bulk Data Storage System: repository for raw public bulk data
      • For Researcher
    • Patent Assignment Dataset details information of patent assignment since 1970 with schema and description and code
    • Pre-Grant Publications Data Download Tables with example code note that organizaiton here is different from Compustat and CRSP, hard to match.
    • Patent Examiniation Data system: records of USPTO patent application, patent filing status and transaction history data
    • Trademark Assignment Dataset
    • Patent Assignment Dataset
    • Duke Innovation
  • Matched US patents to CRSP 1926 - 2010: Leonid Kogan, Dimitris Papanikolaou, Amit Seru, and Noah Stoffman. Description
    • Maintainer with code

Recognizing Patent:

  • Utility: 6 - 8 digits lasts for 20 years from the filed date

Changes to Patent Terms

Year filed Maximum term of validity Act
1790–1835 14 years from issuance Patent Act of 1790
1836–1860 21 years from issuance Patent Act of 1836
1861– 1994 17 years from issuance Congress changed term
1994 - now 20 years from filing Uruguay Round Agreements Act

Table based on wikipedia and USPTO

  • Reissue (RE######)
  • Plant Patent (PP######) lasts for 20 years from the application date
  • Design (D#######) lasts for 14 years from the granted date
  • Additions or Improvements (AI#######)
  • X Patents (X#######)
  • H Documents (H#######)
  • T Documents (T#######)


Worldwide

  • EPO and OECD data
  • wipo



Matching process with CRSP or Compustat

  • KPSS Technological Innovation, Resource Allocation, and Growth
  • UVA Darden Global Corporate Patent Dataset
  • Miao Liu Note that you need Bing API and use Python Github repo
  • NBER Guide

item.title: Linking Financial Databases (CRSP and Compustat)
item.description:
Information can be found in CRSP/COMPUSTAT MERGED DATABASE GUIDE

Change Identifiers:

  • Ticker: can be reassign to another company - abbreviation used to uniquely identify publicly-traded shares of a stock
  • CUSIP: A company can have multiple CUSIPS due to structural changes. - nine-character code assigned by the CUSIP Service Bureau to identify various securities

Permanent Identifiers

  • CRSP (maintained by Chicago BOoth CRSP)
    • PERMCO: is a unique permanent company level identifier (even under name change)
    • PERMNO: is a unique stock (share class) level identifier. One company can have multiple share classes. (1 PERMNO -> 1 PERMCO, 1 -> multiple PERMNOs)
  • Compustat-Capital IQ (maintained by S&P)
    • GVKEY: is a unique number assigned to each company.
